episode.content: Setsuko Thurlow was 13 when the atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima. Horrific scenes of pain and destruction were burned into her memory. She moved to the US and Canada and began to tell the world what had happened in Hiroshima. Her work with the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) overcame resistance from nuclear powers and resulted in the adoption of a UN treaty to ban nuclear weapons. Their efforts earned the group the Nobel Peace Prize. This gripping documentary follows Setsuko's journey from a childhood wracked by war to international recognition.
episode.description: Is a world without nuclear arms possible? Hiroshima bombing survivor Setsuko Thurlow has traveled the globe in pursuit of that goal, a journey which led her to the Nobel Peace Prize Award ceremony.
episode.subtitle: Setsuko Thurlow's Quest: A World Without Nuclear Weapons
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: 80-year-old Dr. Kobori is as old as many of the people he cares for. Every day, he visits his elderly patients at their homes, offering advice and support as well as medical treatment. But sometimes the families who care for these patients require support as well. We follow this dedicated physician as he attends to people at the end of life, ensuring that their final hours are filled with comfort and dignity.
episode.description: Dr. Kobori (80) cares for elderly patients at their homes, offering support to their families. The camera follows him as he ensures that his patients' final days are filled with comfort and dignity.
episode.subtitle: A Doctor Beside the Deathbed
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Plastic pollution litters the world's oceans. It's damaging marine wildlife and ecosystems. A war on plastic is breaking out. In part 1 of this 2-part series, we meet Dutch young pioneer Boyan Slat's team working to clear plastic from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. They have developed a system based on a 600-meter long floating tube. We also look at how microplastics affect living creatures and explore a shocking study that shows how plastic is contributing to rising levels of greenhouse gases.
episode.description: Plastic pollution litters the world's oceans. A war on plastic is breaking out. Part 1 introduces Dutch young pioneer Boyan Slat's team working to clear plastic from the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.
episode.subtitle: No More Plastic: In Search of a Sustainable Future - Part 1: Clearing Plastic from the Ocean
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Plastic pollution litters the world's oceans. The move away from the use of plastic is currently gaining steam around the globe. In part 2 of this series, we look at business trends leading us away from a world of plastic and towards circular economies. One example is a Japanese startup hoping to sell its proprietary recycling technology abroad. And also we look at disposable plastics regulation strategies in France and New York City. Can we find ways to leave our plastic civilization behind?
episode.description: Plastic pollution litters the world's oceans. A war on plastic is breaking out and the goal is a circular economy. Part 2 looks at the latest business trends leading us away from a world of plastic.
episode.subtitle: No More Plastic: In Search of a Sustainable Future - Part 2: Frontlines of Global Business
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Castle design evolved in 17th century Japan with stone walls as a key feature. Sakamoto in Shiga Prefecture became famous for its mason's expert techniques for dry-stacking. They traveled across Japan to complete their commissions. But when feudalism ended 150 years ago, many castles were destroyed. While most of the masons lost their jobs, one family in Sakamoto survived by refurbishing old ruins. But the 15th-generation master Suminori Awata is worried about the future. One day he receives an unexpected request to build a castle-style wall in Texas. Awata's journey begins.
episode.description: Samurai lords used to live in castles with majestic stone walls. Today only a handful of craftsmen can build walls in the traditional way. One such crafstman is working in an unusual place - the U.S.
episode.subtitle: SAMURAI WALL
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Hanzawa Tsuruko is a master of "chaji," a tea ceremony that starts with an exquisitely prepared meal and finishes with matcha tea served from the heart. The purpose of this four-hour event is to treasure every encounter in life, knowing that it will never recur. Tsuruko has been traveling around Japan to encounter new people and share "chaji" with them. Last autumn, at the age of 76, she set off on a tea journey across Germany. The program chronicles her month-long odyssey.
episode.description: Hanzawa Tsuruko is a master of chaji, a tea ceremony that starts with an exquisitely prepared meal and concludes with matcha green tea. Last autumn, she set off on a tea odyssey across Germany.
episode.subtitle: Tsuruko's Tea Journey in Germany
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: "The 72 Pentads of Yamato" produced by NHK Nara has garnered more than 2 million views online from around the world. Each pentad, or five-day season, reflects on the Japanese ideal of living in harmony with nature in Yamato, the ancient name for Nara. The series is created by Nara videographer Hozan Koichi and Kawakami Mine, a pianist who has performed in Spain. Follow Kawakami in her preparations for their next project -- the pinnacle of the series -- a devotional offering at Kasuga Taisha Shrine.
episode.description: Follow pianist Kawakami Mine and videographer Hozan Koichi in their preparations for a musical offering, which reflects on the ideal of living in harmony with nature, at Kasuga Taisha shrine in Nara.
episode.subtitle: The Shape of Sound: A Piano Paints the Seasons of Nara
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Using the latest AI technology, can we defeat our "invisible enemy," the novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19? It was AI that first detected and warned about the infection outbreak, a homepage uses AI to collect and display the latest infection data, and 4 million AI experts are cooperating in a huge online project... In the first part, we report on how researchers on the frontline of the pandemic battlefield are fighting against the explosion of infections with the help of AI.
episode.description: Part1: AI vs. Pandemic. Using the latest AI technology, how close can we get to defeating our "invisible enemy" that causes COVID-19? Researchers on the pandemic battlefield provide answers.
episode.subtitle: AI vs Pandemic: Part 1
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Using the latest AI technology, can we defeat our "invisible enemy," the novel coronavirus that causes COVID-19? In Part 2, we hear from researchers on the pandemic battlefield frontline who are fighting against the explosion of infections with the help of AI. They include the solo data scientist whose predictions of COVID-19 deaths are the most accurate, the researcher who can detect viral infections from voices and researchers making full use of Fugaku, the world's fastest supercomputer.
episode.description: Part2: AI vs. Pandemic. Using the latest AI technology, how close can we get to defeating our "invisible enemy" that causes COVID-19? Researchers on the pandemic battlefield provide answers.
episode.subtitle: AI vs Pandemic: Part 2
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: 75 years ago, Japan and the US each developed chemical weapons and trained their troops to use them. Near the end of the Pacific War, the Imperial Japanese Army stockpiled vast amounts of poison gas for use as a last resort. The US military, meanwhile, drew up chemical weapons plans that would have devastated Japan. After the war, both the US and Japan concealed the truth concerning these weapons. But newly unearthed documents and personal accounts shed light on this dark legacy.
episode.description: At the end of WWII, both Japan and the US were prepared to use chemical weapons on each other. Newly unearthed documents and personal accounts have finally cast light on this dark legacy.
episode.subtitle: Poisonous Secrets: What did Japan and the US bury?
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: NHK is collaborating with 12 public broadcasters around the world to promote a project called "FACES" to tackle against bullying. FACES is a vast collection of 2 minutes testimony from people who have experienced being bullied. By using the network of partnership in FACES, this special edition aims to share specific efforts to tackle with bullying. Also dialogue between cross-country protagonists using online meeting, we deepen mutual understanding, be considerate, and follow in detail until we find a solution together.
episode.description: FACES is a campaign where people who have experienced bullying raise their voices. Through dialogue with each other, protagonist face their past through and cast hope for an inclusive future.
episode.subtitle: FACES the Special - Voices of Hope for an Inclusive Future -
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: A historic music pub reopened in Koza, Okinawa Prefecture, near Kadena Air Base, in 2019. The owner, rock musician Miyanaga Eiichi, performed for American soldiers who were en route to the front lines during the Vietnam War. Now he tells audiences about how the music expressed soldiers' desires for peace, and recounts the history of the base town. Others whose paths crossed in Koza include a resident whose family home was seized for the air base, a former worker at bars catering to US soldiers, and a US veteran who joined the antiwar movement while in Okinawa. The complex history of a base town is explored.
episode.description: A historic music pub reopened in Koza, Okinawa, near Kadena Air Base. To the sound of 70s rock, memories of US soldiers heading off to war and stories of surviving life in an American base town.
episode.subtitle: Koza, Okinawa: Base Town Blues
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: The final stages of World War II... The islands of Okinawa turned into a theater of war the United States military called "hell." The Battle of Okinawa claimed the lives of at least 120,000 islanders. Women and girls were forced in as army cooks or nurses, boys in their mid-teens molded into soldiers... and sent to the frontline. As most records were lost, families are still wondering how their loved ones were mobilized... and what became of them. But recently discovered documents reveal their unknown stories.
episode.description: UNTOLD STORIES OF THE BATTLE OF OKINAWA: Women and Teens on the Frontline. 75 years after the battle that claimed the lives of over 120,000 locals, recently discovered documents reveal untold stories.
episode.subtitle: UNTOLD STORIES OF THE BATTLE OF OKINAWA: Women and Teens on the Frontline
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Using footage shot at the center of the March 2011 Great East Japan Earthquake and tsunami, we bring you a story of horror and heroism during one of history's worst catastrophes. Vast areas along Japan's Pacific coast were devastated. Entire communities were washed away and residents were forced to evacuate. An accident at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant created a radioactive no-man's-land. But in the days that followed, amid the chaos and confusion, countless people sprang into action to assist victims and search for survivors.
episode.description: After the mega-earthquake and tsunami that hit Japan in 2011, people witnessed scenes of horror and heroism. Experience the three days that followed with footage shot at the center of the disaster.
episode.subtitle: 3/11 - The Tsunami: The First 3 Days
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: After the mega-tsunami hit Japan in 2011, survivors who'd lost everything struggled to recover. Many people lost not only their homes, but loved ones and livelihoods as well. Beloved traditions were in danger of disappearing. Rumors of radioactive crops devastated farms and fisheries. And many residents feared that those who'd been forced to evacuate would never return. Follow their year-long effort to rebuild their communities with exclusive footage filmed at the center of the disaster.
episode.description: After a mega-tsunami hit Japan in 2011, survivors who'd lost everything struggled to recover. Follow their year-long effort after the catastrophe through footage filmed at the center of the disaster.
episode.subtitle: 3/11 - The Tsunami: The First Year
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: In a year when countless sporting events were canceled, an unprecedented long-distance race was born: "UTMB for the planet." Online participants ran a set distance at places around the world. Top pros from Ultra-Trail du Mont-Blanc and world-class runners from Japan were among those involved in the intense challenge. Watch passionate runners bring the world together, at a time when the pandemic has kept people apart.
episode.description: An unprecedented long-distance virtual race was born in 2020. Top pros from Ultra-Trail du Mont-Blanc and world-class runners from Japan were among those involved in the intense challenge.
episode.subtitle: GREAT RACE: You'll Never Run Alone
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Dr. Oichiro Kobori (82) cares for dying patients at their homes. Many live with middle-aged and older children who are cut off from society. One man in his 50s, whose father has terminal cancer, hasn't worked since he was young and has psychological problems. Under Dr. Kobori's guidance, the son learns to care for his father and slowly becomes more engaged with the world around him. Follow the two-year journey as Dr. Kobori and his team help patients and families find comfort at the end of life.
episode.description: In Japan, many dying people live at home with middle-aged and older children who are cut off from society. Follow a doctor's two-year journey to help these families find comfort at the end of life.
episode.subtitle: Gifts from a Parent's Deathbed
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Ever since a massive earthquake and tsunami struck northeastern Japan in 2011, NHK WORLD-JAPAN has been following the lives of children from the disaster area. In "Generation 3.11" we follow their progress a decade on. Some are working to ensure the tragedy is never forgotten. Others are finding ways to help their hometowns flourish once again.
episode.description: Since a massive earthquake and tsunami struck northeastern Japan in 2011, NHK has been following the lives of children from the disaster area. In this program, We cover their progress a decade on.
episode.subtitle: Generation 3.11: A Decade Journey
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: The global commons - our forests, oceans, climate and biodiversity - belong to all who dwell on Earth. And they are facing a crisis. Without major changes over the next decade, their destruction will be irreversible, leading to more abnormal weather and deadlier pandemics. What must be done to ensure our planet remains livable? The Tokyo Forum 2020 brings together the world's foremost thinkers to explore green investment, new business opportunities, and the movement for change in Africa.
episode.description: Our Oceans, forests, biodiversity and climate-the global commons- are at the risk. Experts around the world discuss what must be done over the next decade to ensure that life on Earth survives.
episode.subtitle: Global Commons Stewardship
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Following the March 2011 accident at TEPCO's Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant, everyone within a 20km area was ordered to evacuate. Matsumura Naoto alone stayed put. For 10 years, he has taken care of animals abandoned by those who left. Only a few people have since returned, but the reconstruction is in full swing. Matsumura's home is changing beyond recognition. In Fukushima Monologue, we hear his story. It gives us a chance to reflect on resilience, and what is truly important.
episode.description: Since the 2011 nuclear accident, Matsumura Naoto has been single-handedly caring for abandoned animals in the exclusion zone. Amid disruptive change, he recounts his quest to reclaim a lost life.
episode.subtitle: Fukushima Monologue
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: It's said that victims of war die a second time if their remains aren't returned to their families. This is the case for over one million Japanese nationals who were killed during World War II. And recent reporting has revealed serious flaws in the government's repatriation efforts. The award-winning 2019 program and related reporting by NHK triggered a change in government policy. The English version is edited to reflect this development.
episode.description: The remains of over a million people killed in World War Two have not been returned to their families in Japan. Recent reporting reveals serious flaws in government efforts to repatriate war remains.
episode.subtitle: "War Victims Die Twice"
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: The itinerant monk Enku traversed Japan in the 17th century, carving religious sculptures along the way. More than 5,300 distinct statues have been accredited to him to date. Enku is an enigma, but successive findings in recent years have added pieces to the puzzle. One discovery provides more perspective on his elusive early life. What is the significance of the mirror and paper fragments secreted within a wooden statue he carved? New research sheds light on Enku's life and inner workings.
episode.description: 17th-century itinerant monk Enku carved multitudinous statues around Japan during his travels. New research and discoveries help scholars shed light on his elusive early life and inner workings.
episode.subtitle: Enku: The Enigma of a Wandering Sculptor Monk
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: After the massive earthquake of March 11, 2011 struck his hometown Minamisanriku, photographer Sato Shinichi quickly evacuated to high ground with nothing but his camera. A tsunami of unprecedented scale would soon claim the lives of many of his fellow residents. In its aftermath he created a photographic record of what followed. Some 300,000 images in all. 10 years later, we peer through his lens to discover the despair and regret as well as the hope and will to recover of his fellow survivors.
episode.description: 10 years after March 11, 2011, the photographs of Sato Shinichi, 300,000 in all, express pain and regret, as well as hope and the will to recover of his fellow survivors in the town of Minamisanriku.
episode.subtitle: Recovery in 300,000 Pictures
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: Under his motto, "shine a light on a small corner of the world," Dr. Nakamura Tetsu devoted his life to aiding the people of Afghanistan, until he was shot to death there in December 2019. For decades, he treated patients and built clinics to provide ongoing care to underserved people. When devastating droughts hit the country, he launched projects to build irrigation canals. Assisting the doctor's efforts were about one hundred young Japanese, who the doctor referred to as "workers." Some came after suffering setbacks in Japan. Others arrived with a vision of making a difference in the world. In this program, they reflect on how their time with Nakamura changed their lives, and how the doctor's voice reverberates in their hearts still today.
episode.description: For decades before he was killed in 2019, Dr. Nakamura Tetsu devoted his life to aiding the Afghan people. Young Japanese who assisted his efforts reflect on how that experience changed their lives.
episode.subtitle: Hearing the Voice of Nakamura Tetsu
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME

episode.content: The January attack on the US Capitol shocked the world. In the crowd that day was retired teacher Jennifer Marler protesting that "Our voices are not being heard." In the midst of the pandemic, divisiveness has accelerated, rocking the foundation of democracy. What is at the root of people's discontent and anger? We interviewed a father and daughter who clash over immigration policy and the income gap, and a woman who spread QAnon conspiracy theories on the Internet. Social scientists weigh in on the question of where the world is headed.
episode.description: The crisis of democracy has intensified during the pandemic. As crowds attacked the US Capitol in January, we followed a protester to learn what drove them. We explore what fuels this changing world.
episode.subtitle: Social Media and the Tides of Democracy
episode.title: NHK WORLD PRIME
